    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³The meaning of the characters for yin and yang, necessarily, has more than just      Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³one connotation. Because yang means "sunny", it corresponds to the day and more      Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³active functions, whereas yin, meaning "shady", corresponds to night and dormancy.   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³Yin and yang can be compared in the chart to the right. It is also possible to look  Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³at yin and yang with respect to the flow of time. Noon, is full yang, sunset is yang Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³time can also be expressed in seasonal changes and directions. South and Summer are  Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³full yang; West and Autumn are yang turning to yin; North and Winter are full yin,   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³and East and Spring are yin turning over to yang. The major and minor numbers for    Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³Yin and Yang both total up to 15. Yin and yang are often used in reference to        Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³disease, and many Asian cultures treat the hot/cold or wet/dry diseases with oppositeÃ‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³treatments. For example, a yin symptom such as coldness would be treated with yang   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³treatments, such as hot foods. A yang symptom such as nervousness would be treated   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³with yin treatments- cold foods such as fruits. Yin and yang can also be seen as a   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³process of transformation which describes the changes between the phases of a cycle. Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³For example, cold water (yin) can be boiled and eventually turn into steam (yang).   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³One way to write the symbols for yin and yang are a solid line (yang) and a broken   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³line (yin) which could be divided into the four stages of yin and yang and further   Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³divided into the eight trigrams (these trigrams are used on the South Korean flag).  Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³The symbol shown at the top righthand corner of this page, called Taijitu (???),     Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³is another way to show yin and yang. The mostly white portion, being brighter, is    Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³yang and the mostly dark portion, being dim, is yin. Each, however, contains the     Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³seed of its opposite. Yin and yang are equally important, unlike the typical         Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
    Ã‚Â²Ã‚Â³dualism of good and evil. The concept is called yin yang, not yang yin, just         Ã‚Â³Ã‚Â±
